node.text:
Astra + Pfizer = ?
Moderna + Sinovac = ?

In some countries, people have received a mixture of Covid vaccines. Nicole Sy breaks down what that could mean for the world's vaccinated, and those still waiting on their first shot. (via @quicktake)

node.title: What Happens When You Mix Covid Vaccines?

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text: Almost 30 years ago, an American court ruled that victims of the Ferdinand Marcos regime in the Philippines should be compensated — setting off one of the most ambitious and valuable treasure hunts of all time. (via @businessweek)

node.title: Where Did Marcos Hide His $10 Billion Fortune?

node.text: An anonymous donor turned a tiny Pacific coast town without a bank into the world's biggest Bitcoin experiment. Here's how life has changed on El Savaldor's Bitcoin beach. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Bitcoin Beach: The Surf Town That Went Crypto

node.text: Airbnb's $100 billion business model is built on strangers trusting each other. When things go horribly wrong, the company's secretive safety team steps in to soothe guests and hosts, help families and prevent PR disasters. (via @businessweek)

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text: The sudden cancellation of Ant Group’s IPO shocked investors, but Beijing's slapdown of Jack Ma was years in the making. And Alibaba and Ant aren't the only tech firms under scrutiny by Chinese regulators.

node.title: How China Lost Patience With Its Loudest Billionaire

node.text:
Plant-based meat used to mean burgers and sausages. Not anymore.

Using techniques from 3D printing to specially cultivated mushrooms, these companies are at the forefront of the next generation of alternative meats: whole cuts. (via @quicktake)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'New Zealand goes into lockdown over single Covid case Bloomberg'.

node.text:
New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern put the nation into a three-day lockdown after the discovery of a single case in Auckland—the first one since February.

While genome sequencing has yet to be completed, the case is assumed to be the highly infectious delta variant, she said.

Auckland and the nearby Coromandel region will stay locked down for seven days.

Under the so-called alert level 4, all schools, public venues and most businesses must close while people are being urged to work from home and wear a face covering if they need to venture out. Tap the link in our bio for more details.

📷: Hagen Hopkins/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021 tagging @bloombergopinion. May be an image of 2 people, child, grass and text that says 'Fathers facea choice: Stay with kids or return to office? BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Parents who had their first child during the past 18 months are having to figure out how to manage commuting, long hours away from home and parenting small children.

"For new fathers, the pandemic might have spawned a long-overdue cultural shift in how to balance workplace and family life," writes @bloombergopinion columnist Conor Sen.

In a study from June last year, 68% of fathers felt closer or much closer to their children since the start of the pandemic. After spending more time with their children than any generation of fathers in living memory, it’s understandable if that formative experience produced a different outlook on their working life.

Are you a new parent who is struggling with return to office? Let us know in the comments.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Billionaire "bottom feeder" buysmls malls that no one else wants EXIT ReFoer RS) Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Igal Namdar scoops up struggling shopping centers at bargain-basement prices, betting he can turn a profit before the last tenants turn out the lights. “Any seller of retail — malls or open air — any size of portfolio, we’re there,” he says. “We can close immediately, as is, where it is, with no due diligence.”

So far, that strategy has netted big gains — as well as lawsuits by tenants and buyers accusing him of allowing properties to slide into disrepair.
Landlords that own lower-end malls, with high proportions of tenants that have fallen behind on rents or shuttered stores, have been hit especially hard by the pandemic. For Namdar, that smells like opportunity. Link in bio for more.

📷: A nearly empty wing of the Regency Square Mall in Florida in 2019. By Max Marbut/Jacksonville Daily Record

node.text:
“I stand squarely behind my decision,” President Joe Biden said as he addressed the U.S. from the East Room of the White House. “After 20 years, I’ve learned the hard way that there was never a good time to withdraw U.S. forces.”

Biden defended his decision to withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan, pushing back forcefully on criticism of the move that pitched the country into chaos as the Taliban reasserted control.

Biden said the U.S. would continue to fight terrorism in Afghanistan even after the pullback and noted that former President Donald Trump had already drawn down the U.S. presence in the country to a fraction of its previous size after reaching a deal with the Taliban last year in Qatar.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Afghan ceasefire deal struck in Doha collapsed after president fled Bloomberg'.

node.text:
EXCLUSIVE: A tentative ceasefire deal between the Taliban and the Afghan government fell apart when President Ashraf Ghani fled the country, according to two people familiar with the matter.

The weeks leading up to Kabul’s collapse saw a flurry of diplomatic activity by the U.S. and its allies in Qatar aimed at heading off exactly the chaotic scenes in the Afghan capital that have so horrified the world and put Joe Biden’s presidency on the defensive.

Afghan and Taliban negotiators tentatively reached a deal in which all sides would declare a two-week ceasefire in exchange for Ghani’s resignation and the start of talks on setting up a transitional government. His decision to leave Afghanistan surprised his negotiating team in Doha, American diplomats and even his chief of staff and other top aides, said the people. Read more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of airplane and outdoors.

node.text:
With all other exit routes sealed off, the Kabul international airport has become the focal point for thousands of Afghans desperate to leave their country that has now returned to Taliban control.

Images show people crowded onto runways, clamoring onto planes and dangling children over barriers to reach the tarmac. The desperation highlights the level of fear that the Taliban will put the country back under fundamentalist rule, punishing those perceived to have allied with the U.S. or the administration of former President Ashraf Ghani, and curtailing the rights of women.

Reuters reports there have been 5 deaths in the melee. The U.S. has stationed troops at the airport to try and bring the situation under control and to facilitate the evacuation of American diplomats and other staff. Find out more at the link in bio.

📷 : Wakil Kohsar/AFP/Getty Images, Haroon Sabawoon/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, people walking and outdoors.
Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'Junior bankers' raises widen arecord pay gap among collegegrads 2021 Bloomberg'.

node.text:
After a recent wave of raises meant to address complaints that investment banking analysts work too hard for too little, this year’s new recruits will get salaries of at least $100,000 (plus five-figure bonuses).

That means junior bankers are now on track to earn almost five times — or more — the median wage of fellow young college graduates, Census Bureau data show. Banking and a few other industries, including technology, engineering and consulting, now account for the vast majority of jobs in the top 10% of entry-level salaries, according to data from Glassdoor. Now they’re pulling even further ahead of their counterparts in a long list of other professional fields, where wages have stagnated for decades. Read more at the link in bio.

📷: Spencer Platt/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of car, road and text that says '4T U.S. opens formal probe into Tesla's Autopilotsystem Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The U.S. has opened a formal investigation of Tesla’s Autopilot system, citing collisions with parked emergency vehicles.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened at least 30 special crash investigations involving Tesla cars that it suspected were linked to Autopilot, with the pace of probes picking up under the Biden administration. Tesla shares fell as much as 2.4% before the start of regular trading. Tap the link in bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'How a27-year-old built a $3 billion fortune after an allergic reaction Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Johnny Boufarhat is now one of the world’s youngest self-made billionaires. It all started because he was fed up.

A rare allergic reaction in 2015 left him with a misfiring immune system, making him crave in-person contact. “It was so bad that for years, I could barely go outside,” the 27-year-old wrote in a blog post. “I wanted to go to events. I wanted to meet people.”

In 2019, that frustration led him to start writing code in his London kitchen for an online events platform, Hopin. 

This month, the startup raised $450 million from investors including Brad Gerstner’s Altimeter Capital Management at a $7.8 billion valuation. 

Technology and the ease of raising venture capital has created far greater numbers of new billionaires than ever before and at increasingly younger ages. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'Panicked citizens flood Kabul's airport fleeAfghanistan Bloomberg erg'.

node.text:
Desperate scenes are playing out at Kabul’s international airport. Thousands of citizens rushed to flee Afghanistan after Taliban fighters took control of the capital.

Reuters reported at least five people were killed as people tried to forcibly enter planes leaving the country.

The U.S. announced late Sunday it was taking steps to secure the airport in its rush to evacuate thousands of American citizens, as well as locally employed staff and their families. Tap the link in our bio for the latest.

:: AFP via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Ready for Ethereum 2.0? Here's how the big update will work. Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Ethereum is making big changes.

The most important is the jettisoning of the “miners” who track and validate transactions on the world’s most-used blockchain network. The system has come under increasing criticism for its environmental impact. Bitcoin miners now use as much electricity as some small nations.

Along with being greener and faster, proponents say the switch will illustrate another difference between Ethereum and Bitcoin: A willingness to change, and to see the network as a product of community as much as code. Tap the link in bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 15, 2021. May be an image of 5 people, beard, people standing and text that says 'Taliban take control of Afghanistan after 20 years fighting the U.S. Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Taliban leaders took over the presidential palace in Kabul and said they plan to soon declare a new "Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan," two decades after they were removed by the U.S. military.

The nation's U.S.-backed president, Ashraf Ghani, fled the country. The military is also in disarray, providing little to no resistance as the militants advanced across cities.

The Taliban swept through Afghanistan in a matter of weeks, taking advantage of a vacuum left by departing U.S. and NATO forces working against President Joe Biden’s Aug. 31 deadline to end America’s longest war. Read the latest developments at the link in bio.

📷: Taliban fighters take control of the presidential palace. Photographer: Zabi Karimi/AP
